column1: 1_u	"This is a very strange film that was long thought to be forgotten. It's the story of two American Army buddies
column2: William Boyd (aka ""Hopalong Cassidy"") and Louis Wolheim
column3: and their adventures as they manage to escape from a German prison camp during WWI. However
column5: the duo manage to make the most round about and stupid escape--accidentally boarding a train to Constantinople to be placed in a Turkish prisoner of war camp! On the way
column6:
they manage to escape once again and end up in quite the adventure--meeting sexy Mary Astor along the way.

As far as the film goes
column7: it was a rather funny script and despite being a silly plot
column8: it worked rather well. The chemistry between Boyd and Wolheim worked and the film managed to be quite entertaining. Oddly
column10: the film managed to beat out Harold Lloyd's film
column12: for an Oscar for Best Direction for a Comedy (a category no longer used)--as SPEEDY was a superior film in most ways (it's one of Lloyd's best films). Still
column13:
it's well worth a look--especially if you love silent films.

By the way
column14: director Milestone and Louis Walheim would team up just a few years later for another WWI picture
column15: the great ALL QUIET ON THE WESTERN FRONT--a film that is definitely NOT a comedy."

column1: 24095_u	With a savage murderer stalking the night
column2:
dark suspicion swirls about THE LODGER living in a London home.

Sir Alfred Hitchcock (1899-1980) became a director of note with this silent film
column3: his first thriller and only his third directorial effort
column4: which shows the young Master's talents being developed in embryo. Based on the novel by Mrs. Belloc Lowndes and the tales of Jack the Ripper
column5: Hitchcock was able to embroider upon the theme of mistaken identities and incorporate an intense chase sequence
column6: both of which would become important elements in his later suspense films. He also made the first of his famous cameo appearances
column8:
which would also become part of his trademark.

The film is well plotted and moody
column9: told in an almost expressionistic style
column10: relying mainly on visuals and a somewhat frugal use of title cards. The staging in the narrow
column11: multi-level home is especially well managed
column12:
with characters on different stories interacting in the plot simultaneously.

Fans of the 1944 American remake with Laird Cregar may be surprised at its very different ending from this film. This is probably largely due to the fact that the earlier movie (including some very incongruous and never explained plot elements) was planned as a showcase for its star
column14: who plays the title role. Born David Ivor Davies in Wales
column15: Novello (1893-1951) was the son of famed singing teacher Dame Clara Novello Davies. He found success on the stage at an early age and became a very popular actor-manager
column17: his most lauded song being the World War One patriotic tune 'Keep The Home Fires Burning.' Although he appeared occasionally in films
column18: Novello's greatest renown came from his acting in the lavishly romantic stage plays he authored
column19: his handsome good looks being especially appreciated by the ladies in the audience. A hint of his melodramatic stage persona
column20: especially the use of his mesmeric eyes
column21: can be seen in Hitchcock's film
column22:
projecting the actor into a virtual Epiphany during the most exciting sequence. Novello would also star in THE LODGER's 1932 British talkie remake.

The rest of the cast does well in support of Novello

column24: whose character is done rather dirty by the script

Soon it is found out that Paulie gave some guy a blank check signed by Rocky or something and that they lost all their money. So they are forced to move back to Philadelphia. Further issues show up when it is revealed that Rocky has suffered head trauma and further boxing can seriously injure him (watching this movie could also give you head trauma).

However Rocky re opens the old boxing gym since Mickey willed it over to Rocky Jr. Now living in the old neighborhood Rocky Jr. begins school and is immediately beaten up by bullies. Rocky meanwhile meets up with a young boxer named Tommy Gunn whom wants Rocky to manage him but Rocky decides he is not a good enough listener. He latter changes his mind and agrees to train Tommy Gunn and begins to spend more time with Tommy than his own son and dissension soon forms between father and son.

TOmmy Gunn moves up the ranks. George Washington meanwhile tries to lure Gunn away from Rocky by lavishing wealth and women upon him. Rocky Jr. beats up the bullies that bugged him. Gunn leaves Rocky and immediately battles Union Caine for the heavyweight champion title and wins it. Rocky and Jr. talk and patch things up. After winning the title Gunn is hassled by reporters who argue that him winning the belt is meaningless since he never beat Rocky to obtain it and because Caine was a paper champion.

column1: 41728_u	Silent Scream starts with one of the most annoying opening sequences I've seen in a while. An entire scene involving police pulling up outside
